results.title: Green Fingers: Weed Control
results.brief_description: ‘Green Fingers’ was a series of short instructional films on home gardening tips, produced by the Victorian Department of Agriculture. In this episode, ‘Weed Control’, gardener Rod Cantrill demonstrates how to control weeds in the home garden. Cantrill shows a range of methods for managing weeds, including hoeing, mulching and herbicides, accompanied by a narrator who explains the benefits and correct techniques of each method. The episodes of ‘Green Fingers’ are an early example of popular gardening shows in the tradition of ‘Sow What’, ‘Better Homes and Gardens’, and ‘Gardening Australia’.

results.title: Green Fingers: Planting Evergreens
results.brief_description: ‘Green Fingers’ was a series of short instructional films on home gardening tips, produced by the Victorian Department of Agriculture. In this episode, ‘Planting Evergreens’, gardener Rod Cantrill demonstrates how to correctly plant evergreen trees and shrubs in your garden, accompanied by a narrator explaining the method and techniques. The episodes of ‘Green Fingers’ are an early example of popular gardening shows in the tradition of ‘Sow What’, ‘Better Homes and Gardens’, and ‘Gardening Australia’.

results.title: Ariarne Titmus’ coach Dean Boxall on her winning gold
results.brief_description: Australians were in a frenzy of excitement when Ariarne Titmus won gold in the women’s 400m freestyle in her Olympic debut in Tokyo. Managing to dethrone previous Olympic medallist Katie Ledecky, Titmus later spoke of the pain and years of dedication it took to win. Knowing her journey full well, no one else was more ecstatic than her coach, Dean Boxell.
results.title_for_label: Ariarne Titmus’ coach Dean Boxall on her winning gold
results.description:
This video features in a responsive display in the museum that presents the moments, stories and memes capturing the zeitgeist by going viral on the internet.

Australians were in a frenzy of excitement when Ariarne Titmus won gold in the women’s 400m freestyle in her Olympic debut in Tokyo. After dethroning defending champion Katie Ledecky, Titmus revealed the years of dedication it took to win, telling Sunrise: “Physically, it’s a lot of training. On the days that I’m at the pool twice a day I could be there up to seven or eight hours and Dean is there a lot longer.”

Knowing her journey full well, no one else was more ecstatic than her coach, Dean Boxell, whose enthusiastic celebration was thrust into the limelight across social media.

Boxell was captured enthusiastically dancing, punching the air, screaming in joy, and yes, air-humping the glass barrier in celebration. His vigorous outpouring almost immediately went viral, spreading across local news, Twitter and Instagram after countless Olympic viewers filmed their TV screens and shared it online. Many were right there with him, finding his gut reaction honest, endearing and typically Australian.

But others found the display over the top and offensive, leading to a backlash from some Twitter users, especially Americans. Was this something that only Australian audiences could understand? Or was this an example of inflated male privilege? Titmus certainly didn’t mind at all and was thrilled to share the moment with her fervently loyal coach, who was inspired by his favourite wrestler from childhood, Ultimate Warrior.

“He is my favourite. I used to wrestle with my brother … I loved the Ultimate Warrior,” he has said.
description_for_label:
This responsive display presents the moment, stories ad memes capturing the zeitgeist by going viral on the internet.

Australians were in a frenzy of excitement when Ariarne Titmus won gold in the women’s 400m freestyle in her Olympic debut in Tokyo. After dethroning defending champion Katie Ledecky, Titmus revealed the years of dedication it took to win. Knowing her journey full well, no one was more excited than coach Dean Boxell, whose celebration was thrust into the limelight across social media.

details.label: Curatorial section
display_values: The Story of the Moving Image → Moving Minds → 09. Catch of the Day

results.title: Jeff Bezos post-launch brief
results.brief_description:
Following Jeff Bezos’ launch into space on the New Shephard rocket ship, the billionaire took a moment to thank those who had made it possible. The ten-minute, $5.5 billion trip was essentially bankrolled by Amazon customers and employees – the latter of whom are renowned for being criminally overworked and underpaid. During a period of historic inequality, a billionaire blasting off a planet ravaged by the climate crisis and a pandemic seemed tone-deaf at best, villainous at worst.

It also wasn’t lost on many social media users how phallic the New Shephard’s shape seemed to be, generating an avalanche of quips suggesting Bezos was overcompensating for… something. Naturally, the internet didn’t take long to compare the New Shephard to the rocket launched by Dr Evil in Austin Powers: The Spy Who Shagged Me. While these jokes may seem throw-away moments of internet culture, they, like others referencing his recent divorce, use humour and absurdity to bring Bezos back down to earth. And the backlash isn’t only against the Amazon founder, but also Richard Branson and Elon Musk, billionaires jostling to beat each other into the stratosphere in a space race that exposes how massive corporations and individuals now possess the resources to do what was once reserved for Cold War superpowers. While Bezos timed the launch on the anniversary of the 1969 Moon landing, many Twitter users noted the disparity between that globally unifying moment and the disillusionment of watching a man who could end poverty take an intergalactic joyride.

details.label: Curatorial section
display_values: The Story of the Moving Image → Moving Minds → 09. Catch of the Day

results.title: Eye of fire
results.brief_description: A gas leak in an underwater pipeline caused an oceanic fireball dubbed ‘The Eye of Fire’ in the Gulf of Mexico. The state owned company is investigating the causes.

constellations_other.name: Deep blue
constellations_other.description: Go deep on an exploration of real world oceans and those rendered by pixels and creatures made from plastics.

results.title_for_label: ‘Eye of fire’ in the Gulf of Mexico
results.description:
This video features in a responsive display in the museum that presents the moments, stories and memes capturing the zeitgeist by going viral on the internet.

In horrific scenes that seemed more like footage from an action movie than the real world, the ocean was literally on fire on 3 July 2021 in the Gulf of Mexico. The huge fireball blazing across the sea surface was caused by a gas leak from an underwater pipeline, which social media users dubbed ‘the eye of fire’. The video was shared across the internet as further evidence of the environmental tolls of capitalism and the irresponsibility of fossil fuel companies plundering natural resources and producing unnatural results.
description_for_label:
This responsive display presents the moments, stories and memes capturing the zeitgeist by going viral on the internet.

In astonishing scenes, the ocean was literally on fire on 3 July 2021 in the Gulf of Mexico. The fireball blazing across the sea surface, dubbed the ‘eye of fire’ by social media users, was caused by an underwater gas leak from a pipeline. The video spread across the internet as further evidence of fossil fuel companies plundering natural resources and producing unnatural results.
